;在第二次大觉醒期间，十九世纪初席卷美国的宗教狂热浪潮，自称为先知的约翰·乔治·拉普 (John George Rapp) 创立了印第安纳州哈莫尼 (Harmony) 镇。 1820 年左右，他的追随者建造了一座迷宫，中心有一座小神殿；他们用它来冥想在千禧年到来之前灵魂将面临的许多错误道路。当千禧年未能到来，拉普的个人崇拜开始瓦解时，该定居点被卖给了富有的苏格兰实业家罗伯特·欧文，他将其重新命名为“新和谐”，并邀请了数百名普通民众以及当时的一些伟大学者，加入他自己的乌托邦实验。欧文的放荡、理性主义的“社会科学”与拉普的禁欲、专制的“圣经共产主义”截然相反。但它还是失败了。小镇陷入混乱，欧文放弃了新和谐，迷宫一直被忽视，直到 1939 年，当地的一个保护协会建造了一个新迷宫。

;

;第一批参观新迷宫的人之一是印第安纳州诗人玛格丽特·杨（Marguerite Young），摩门教领袖杨百翰的后裔。杨是一位文学神童，六岁时写下了她的第一首诗，当时她正在创作一系列关于拉普和欧文乌托邦实验的民谣。这个项目的发展远远超出了最初的范围，这后来成为了她的一种模式。杨放弃了散文中限制性的民谣形式，将她的新和谐历史出版为“;森林中的天使：两个人的童话乌托邦;”，1945 年。

;

;“我的主题一直是失乐园”，1995 年，杨在去世前不久对一位采访者说道。 《森林中的天使》生动地描绘了十九世纪“顽固的梦想家”——不仅是拉普和欧文，还有乔治三世和维多利亚女王——以伊丽莎白一世和詹姆士一世时代作家的诗意散文描绘了他们的形象。这是她在芝加哥大学攻读硕士学位的主题。这本书探讨了将“幻觉变成事实”的幻想所产生的尖锐讽刺。 “没有什么比失败的记忆更令人难忘，”杨写道，“尤其是当它追求极致完美时。”对于杨来说，印第安纳州乌托邦的迷人与幻灭的循环是民族性格的本质。

;

;《森林中的天使》被提名为国家年度最佳非小说类图书奖艺术与文学学院。如果“;Moderate Fable;，”杨的另一本书，没有获得同样的诗歌奖那年。凭借这次表演和简短的写作样本，杨将她的下一个项目——一部暂定名为《麦子里的虫》的小说——卖给了麦克斯韦·珀金斯，传奇的斯克里布纳编辑，他发现了;菲茨杰拉德;，;海明威;和托马斯·沃尔夫。

;

;杨设想这本书的页数最多可达 200 页左右，需要两年时间才能完成。十八年后，当她将手稿交给斯克里布纳时，那叠纸几乎有她身高的一半。与此同时，杨获得了一套新住所（她将在那里度过大部分人生的格林威治村公寓）、一位新编辑（巴勒斯·米切尔）、一系列新的荣誉（古根海姆、纽伯里图书馆和洛克菲勒基金会奖学金） ，以及她现在史诗般比例的小说的新标题：“;麦金托什小姐，亲爱的;。”杨也用纸和墨水而不是灌木和木头重建了和谐主义迷宫。然而，在她的版本中，中心并没有等待被发现的神殿。

;

;在《麦金托什小姐，亲爱的》中，美国梦被毫不夸张地描述为：一系列不相容的幻觉。故事主要发生在大萧条最后几年的一次令人痛苦的夜间公交车之旅中，故事讲述了叙述者维拉侧手翻，她仔细回忆自己在新英格兰海岸一座豪宅中古怪的成长经历。维拉的母亲凯瑟琳·海伦娜·卡特惠尔（Catherine Helena Cartwheel）是一位传奇美女和前社交名流，在维拉的父亲“职业游手好闲者”去世后，她就隐居在这所房子里。凯瑟琳吸食了大量鸦片。她每天都在自己创造的巴洛克式梦幻世界中度过，在满是真人大小的国际象棋棋子和跑调的三角钢琴的场地上漫步。她与她的枝形吊灯 Mr. Chandelier 和她的药瓶 Mr. Res Tacamah 交谈，并招待了她邀请的一群想象中的历史人物来喝茶。

;

;这座宅邸的工作人员有一群随从仆人和凯瑟琳忠实的杂役约阿希姆·斯皮策先生是一位失败的作曲家，他的爱没有得到回报，因为凯瑟琳更喜欢他的同卵双胞胎庇隆，一个已经去世多年的赌徒。尽管斯皮策先生病态优柔寡断，但他的任务是寻找一位家庭教师来抚养维拉。他选择了名义上的乔治亚·麦金托什（Georgia MacIntosh），一个鼻子骨折的红发保姆，没有要求任何角色参考。

;
;
;

;麦金托什小姐的教学原则非同寻常。其中包括来自“;穷理查德年鉴;，来自“农民年鉴”的事实，原始教会教义她的传教士兄弟，以及曾经是中心地带小镇精神特征的实用主义、禁欲主义和小“r”共和主义。她的目标是让她的下属成为一个勤劳、恭顺的未来妻子，但她一心一意地追求自己的议程，就像凯瑟琳一样脱离现实，她反对凯瑟琳的奢华品味。典型的一堂课是，维拉被要求陈述堪萨斯州的人口，背诵穆迪圣经的家谱或“伟大的棒球之王”，或者听关于股市投资必要性的半生不熟的布道。麦金托什小姐非常重视实践技能和体育教育，因此她和维拉修补船帆和外套上的洞，锤击腐烂的栅栏和破损的木筏上的木板，并围着红球追逐。

;

;最终，它变成了显然，在她对“朴素美德”和“赤裸裸的简单”真理的赞歌中，麦金托什小姐的抗议太过分了。在维拉十四岁生日那天，她发现了关于她家庭女教师的一个秘密，导致后者在海中溺水身亡，显然是自杀。维拉多年来一直为失去“亲爱的”而哀悼。当一场暴风雨吞噬了豪宅和她的母亲时，她决定接受麦金托什小姐的建议“自力更生”。她将“看到美国……” 。 。广阔的内陆，宽敞的中西部，那种生活不需要邪恶想象的媒介来阻挡自己和简单事物的清晰现实。”

;

;维拉的目标是达到爱荷华州的What Cheer，麦金托什小姐长大的地方。她只到达了印第安纳州西南部。在小说的最后一幕中，她下了公交车，入住了一家酒店，该酒店曾经是和谐主义者的宿舍和欧文派的小酒馆。薇拉远没有经历麦金托什小姐所承诺的“正常生活”，而是会遇到中西部的人物，比如醉酒的公交车司机摩西·亨内克(Moses Hunnecker)，他拒绝剪头发以抗议罗斯福的政策，或者永远怀孕的女服务员埃丝特·朗特里(Esther Longtree) ，她只生下死产——事实证明，这些孩子的幻想并不比她在新英格兰的童年少。

;
;
;

;正如她的名字所暗示的，维拉遇到了不断翻转的真相再次翻转并右侧朝上。在杨的讲述中，现实并不是不同看法重叠的中立地带；而是一个中立的世界。这是它们之间的间隙。正如小说的暂定标题所言，现实是麦子里的虫子，在这一点上，我们的“完美方程”会出现问题，我们的“定义会失败”，而我们对“最终和谐”的渴望也会受到挫败。维拉被迫得出结论，真相“不过是另一种幻觉”。正如杨在《森林中的天使》中描述的两个乌托邦一样，你可以用一种生命理论“替代”另一种生命理论，并得到相同的结果。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;维拉大部分时间都在听其他人说话，但她也能部分地讲述这本书因为她调和了母亲和保姆看似对立的世界观。她逐渐同意凯瑟琳的观点，“现实总是伴随着宿命般的失望”，而与幻想和平相处恰恰是“整个生命所依赖的”。然而，与凯瑟琳不同的是，她放弃了对“完美幸福”的追求，麦金托什小姐可能会赞同这一务实的举动。尽管维拉从未参加过What Cheer，但她并不绝望。 “一个人仍然达到了自己的目标，”她推理道，“即使这不是预期的目标。 。 。无论发现什么，都是真实的。”薇拉在《麦金托什小姐，我的亲爱的》结尾找到了小说中完美追求者所没有的东西：爱。

;

;《麦金托什小姐，我的亲爱的》在 1965 年问世时取得了巨大的成功. ;诺曼·梅勒;对杨的成就印象深刻，将她拉到一边在一次聚会上，她询问她家里是否有拳击手，“因为像这样在木屑圈里晃来晃去，打了十八年，需要很大的力气。” （他后来给斯克里布纳写了一封信，称杨为“穿着高跟鞋的温柔大力士”，宣传部门立即将其变成了梅勒和杨决斗的漫画。）杨的前学生，;库尔特·冯内古特;说她“毫无疑问是一个天才”，她的朋友阿纳伊斯·宁称赞她创造的“完整的宇宙”。 《纽约时报》将杨的散文与;梅尔维尔;、;乔伊斯;和;福克纳;。其他评论家引用了“伟大的美国小说”这个词。

;

;我们对过热的赞扬越来越警惕，但不可能谈论刚刚由达尔基档案馆重新发行的《麦金托什小姐，我的亲爱的》新闻，没有最高级。该书长达 1,198 页，是最长的单卷英文小说之一。如果“;Moby-Dick;”，所有其他伟大的美国小说都反对这本书衡量一下，是关于一个偏执狂的，“麦金托什小姐”是名副其实的亚哈共和国，每个人都比下一个更独特。印第安纳州的一辆公共汽车和新英格兰的一座豪宅为这本书提供了主要背景，但杨和梅尔维尔一样，总是给它们注入宇宙论的意义。 （在一个场景中，薇拉望着公交车窗外，将“中西部水汪汪的灰色”比作“只有上帝的灵在深渊上运行时的第一次创造”的场景。）这本书是一部史诗母亲和女儿的关系，而不是父亲和儿子、丈夫和妻子的关系，或者战争与和平的关系，以及杨的句子，它们结合了;惠特曼;与纳博科夫相比，是美国小说家有史以来最精湛的作品之一。

;

;据宁说，尽管《麦金托什小姐》第一年就卖出了四万册， ”未能给公众留下太多印象。这并不奇怪。小说的长度本身就让大多数读者望而却步。就像其结构所基于的和谐主义迷宫一样，它很容易迷失方向。这本书提出了谜团，找到了解决方案，然后转向长达数百页的题外话。直到最后一章为止，它都添加了次要角色，给人的印象是它可以无限期地继续下去。因果关系就像在凯瑟琳的鸦片梦中一样确定无疑，而通常被认为是对立的状态——想象与现实、生与死、女性与男性、过去与未来——转换或融合。杨的“转换”句子（用她的造词）与其说是逐行进步，不如说是通过短语和意象的重复和变化而积累的：

;
;
;

;和斯皮策先生，不过非常悲哀，不应该认为他的伟大作品真的丢失了，因为没有人梳理过所有音乐的海洋，这些伟大的梳理者滚动，所有反射的星星和海星在涨潮时骑行，或者探索无意识，钓鱼伟大的珍珠——因为没有一部伟大的音乐作品，甚至是他尚未演奏的伟大音乐，曾被如此明确地写成一波又一波的汹涌波涛，其所有可闻和不可闻的声音和铿锵有力的诗篇触动了羽毛般的云朵和颤抖的喉咙和舌头金色的钟声像火一样燃烧，彩色的颜色苍白，就像哨兵海豚在飞蛾颜色的岩石上死去的颜色，黑色的音符像黑鸟飞过头顶，护送他穿过玻璃般的云海，巨大的银色钟声和号角洒满了声音和喇叭。死琴如骨，死骨吟唱，空舟荡漾，可以弹奏。 。 。因为没有人可以发出这样的深度，这是开始的音乐，这是结束的音乐，永无止境

;像这样阅读十几页的体验就是感官超载和注意力耗尽。用学者史蒂文·沙维罗的话说，“太多了”。与美国没什么不同。

;

;杨在六十年代剩下的时间里从事反战活动，在福特汉姆和新学院教授英语和创意写作。她放弃了新哈莫尼出生的诗人约翰·惠特科姆·莱利（《小孤儿安妮》和《衣衫褴褛的人》的作者）的传记，转而推荐一本关于他的朋友的传记;尤金·V·德布斯;，五次社会主义总统候选人。当她去世时，“;激进的竖琴歌曲;”尚未出版，已经膨胀到大约两千五百页。

;

;直到今天，杨仍然是一位狂热的作家。尽管充满八卦和性别歧视，她的《泰晤士报》讣告准确地描述了她的地位：“格林威治村怪人”，而不是二十世纪最雄心勃勃的小说之一的作者。也许达尔基的重新发行会引发重新评估——但是，还有人关心这部伟大的美国小说吗？自从这个词在 18 世纪 60 年代被创造以来，美国人经历了对这个想法的着迷和失望的循环。在每一代人中，都会有一些小说家试图写出这样的小说，这让评论家和学者们感到懊恼，他们往往认为这个概念充其量只是一种中庸的客厅游戏，最坏的情况是具有排他性。正如学者劳伦斯·布尔（Lawrence Buell）所写，如果“伟大的美国小说的梦想”是“不可扼杀的”，那是因为它源于一种欲望，就像激发拉普和欧文的欲望一样乌托邦。

;
;
;

;我们知道，乌托邦的生活始于小说。很少有人承认的是，每部小说都是乌托邦——而不仅仅是因为它发生在想象的“虚无”中。在对这部伟大的美国小说的批评之下，人们发现了一种不那么微妙的夸耀：美国的经历太复杂、太多样化、地理范围太广、太难以驾驭，无法用一部史诗来概括。这无疑是事实；同时，它误解了伟大的美国小说的社会功能是什么。它不仅仅是一种流派；它是一种流派。它是一种工具，旨在帮助我们在叙事中管理我们对完美的挫败渴望。 “梦想永远不会完成，”维拉说。 “即使梦想是完整的，它也总是不完整的。”在美国，就像在文学中一样，“梦想就足够了”。 ♦

;A few years ago, advertisements for a software service named Monday.com seemed to be suddenly everywhere online. This ubiquity didn't come cheap. An SEC filing revealed that the product's developers had spent close to a hundred and thirty million dollars on advertising in 2020 alone, which amounted to roughly eighty per cent of the company's annual revenue. The resulting blitz generated more than seven hundred and twenty-two million views on Monday.com's YouTube channel—an audience larger than the preceding four Super Bowls combined.

;

;This outsized investment makes sense when you consider the changes that have taken place in the productivity-software market. Monday.com claims to help knowledge workers collaborate better: “Boost your team's alignment, efficiency, and productivity by customizing any workflow to fit your needs.” This objective might sound dry in our current moment of flashy social apps and ;eerie artificial intelligence;, but helping organizations manage their workflows has proved to be surprisingly lucrative. Trello, one of the early success stories from this category, was launched in 2011 as a side project by an independent software developer. In 2017, it was purchased by Atlassian for four hundred and twenty-five million in cash and stock. Another workflow-management service, named Wrike, subsequently sold for $2.25 billion. For its part, Monday.com went on to leverage the user growth generated by its advertising push to support a successful IPO that valued the company at over seven billion dollars.

;

;What's striking about this new generation of productivity software is not so much what it does, but what it doesn't do. Until recently, most business applications focussed on providing faster and more powerful versions of the tools that knowledge workers were already using to accomplish their daily tasks—electronic spreadsheets were better than paper accounting ledgers, e-mail is better than fax machines. The new productivity services, by contrast, can't be used to directly execute work. Their purpose is instead to help better ;organize; these efforts. Monday.com allows you to arrange “items,” described by various properties such as “status” or “percentage complete,” onto “boards.” You can then visualize the work described by these boards in various useful formats. Trello offers something similar, capturing items on virtual cards that can be dragged around into different vertical stacks. One stack might contain the tasks a team still needs to handle, while another might contain those already accomplished.

;

;To understand the importance of this shift from work to workflow, it helps to understand two competing philosophies about how technology impacts productivity. The first argues that technology improves productivity by directly improving the tools that we work with—the waterwheel, the electric motor, and so on. A less-discussed but equally important philosophy broadens the definition of technology to include the more general systems by which work is organized. It argues that some of the biggest productivity breakthroughs come not from better tools but instead from smarter ways of arranging what you're already doing. A canonical example is Henry Ford's continuous-motion assembly line, developed at his automobile factory in Highland Park, Michigan. The assembly line was a productivity miracle, decreasing the worker hours required to produce a Model T by nearly a factor of ten. Its effectiveness, however, had less to do with ingenious new inventions than it did with an ingenious new insight about how to rearrange the manufacturing process: bringing the car to the worker instead of the worker to the car. “Be ready to revise any system, scrap any method, abandon any theory, if the success of the job requires it,” Ford explained.

;
;
;

;The change of focus in the business-software space from tools toward process-based productivity can be explained, in part, by the acknowledgment that the existing strategy of making applications increasingly powerful has stopped making us better at our jobs. During the past two decades or so—a period of rapid technology innovation, which produced laptops, smartphones, ubiquitous cloud computing, and Google—American productivity growth has suffered a sustained slowdown. We gained access to an armada of supercharged workplace tools, and yet we're not getting much more done.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;There are many explanations for this paradox, including, notably, the theory that these tools counterbalanced new capabilities with new distractions. (E-mail is faster than a fax machine, but its spread also created a world in which we end up ;checking our in-boxes constantly;.) Regardless of specific causes, what is clear is that this general failure of new technology to deliver results in the workplace presents a problem for software developers. If employers no longer believe that these products are significantly boosting their employees' productivity, they'll no longer pay top dollar to keep up with the latest versions. In the nineteen-nineties, Microsoft made a fortune from companies willing to invest in expensive standalone releases of their densely featured Office productivity software. Today, these same companies, less enamored with such tools' productive potential, might instead settle for cheaper online variants. Why spend two hundred and forty-nine dollars for a single copy of Microsoft Office 2021 when business subscriptions to Google's Web-based workplace tools start at six dollars per user? (Perhaps reacting to these pressures, Microsoft now offers a free Web-based version of its once vaunted Office software.)

;

;In this context, the move in business software toward process productivity comes across as a reasonable strategy. It presents a new and exciting pitch for the professional market—“It's not the tools that matter, it's the process!”—and new and exciting pitches are often better able to attract significant investment. If Microsoft Word was the waterwheel, in other words, maybe Monday.com can be the assembly line. This development should be received as good news. The process-centric philosophy of productivity had been largely missing from the world of office work. Whereas other economic sectors have long cared a lot about how effort is organized, knowledge-work managers, ;for a combination of historically contingent reasons;, have traditionally left these details up to individuals. It wasn't until the rapid expansion of the knowledge economy in the second half of the twentieth century that productivity suddenly became personal.

;

;This myopia is a ;mistake;. Keeping productivity as an individual obligation, and focussing only on offering increasingly powerful tools, didn't lead to a more efficient and relaxing workday, but instead enabled us to take on even more tasks, pursued with even more frantic intensity. It doesn't have to be this way. More structured rules for determining who should be working on what, and how collaboration should best be organized, could walk us back from our current moment of always-on overload.

;

;It's here that the rise of process-centric productivity software might generate its most lasting impact. If tools like Monday.com, Trello, and Wrike continue to spread, they will carry in their wake an emphasis on the importance of process productivity. Whether or not these particular applications stick, this new mind-set might, and if it does, it would be a welcome transformation for a knowledge sector exhausted by the focus on tools over systems. These well-funded software companies, competing aggressively to become the next Microsoft, might just provide the strong push needed for the managerial class to realize that there's more to productivity than simply giving their employees the latest spreadsheet and messenger software. It's in rethinking how we organize our work, not just in how fast we can accomplish it, where the real improvements are to be found. Perhaps we're finally ready to learn this reality. ♦

;米特·罗姆尼 (Mitt Romney) 和他的家人聚集在一家经济型酒店房间内。现在是 2008 年 1 月，距离新罕布什尔州初选只有几天了。共和党总统提名候选人罗姆尼坐在高背椅上，穿着他惯用的盔甲：海军蓝色领带、带袖扣的闪亮白衬衫和正装裤。他的妻子安坐在他旁边。他的两个儿子和一个儿媳妇排列在他们周围。罗姆尼的竞选进展不顺利。他在爱荷华州党团会议中惨败给前阿肯色州州长迈克·赫卡比(Mike Huckabee)，而在新罕布什尔州，他似乎又会输给参议员约翰·麦凯恩(John McCain)。 “也许你再等几年？”罗姆尼的一个儿子建议道。罗姆尼似乎否认了这种可能性。 “当这一切结束后，我就会建立一个品牌，”他说。 “人们会认识我的。他们会知道我的立场。”他停了下来。 “狂妄的摩门教，”他说道，脸上露出半微笑。他的家人发出一些窃笑声，更多的是沮丧而不是有趣。随后，族人跪在地上祈祷。罗姆尼低下头，手肘撑在椅子上。安在祈祷中感谢上帝的祝福，并表示全家只想“为您服务，为这个地球带来更大的光明。”

;

;这一刻被 2014 年的纪录片《Mitt》捕捉到，概括了;米特·罗姆尼;的持久悖论。在马萨诸塞州担任温和派州长后，他的标志性成就是颁布了全民医疗保健制度，在两次失败的总统竞选期间，他在意识形态和语气上进行了转变，以引导他的政党的右倾倾向。他从未摆脱过关于他是一个反复无常、缺乏真正信念的人的诽谤。 2008 年，在新罕布什尔州举行的;共和党候选人论坛;期间，麦凯恩转向罗姆尼说：“我们在很多问题上存在分歧，但我同意你是变革的候选人。”在竞选活动中，罗姆尼常常给人一种笔挺、僵硬的印象，就像他熨烫得干脆的正装衬衫一样。选民们很难真正了解他。然而，对于那些进入他的世界的人来说，他的核心始终是显而易见的。这在新罕布什尔州的酒店房间中很明显，在麦凯·科平斯的启发性新传记中也很明显，“;罗姆尼：清算;”，其中这位政治家的摩门教信仰成为滋养他生活中其他一切的基础。

;
;
;

;

;科平斯和《米特》的导演格雷格·怀特利都是耶稣基督后期圣徒教会的成员，这绝非偶然。科平斯依靠对罗姆尼的数十次采访以及数百页的个人日记和私人信件，讲述了罗姆尼的野心和原则日益陷入冲突时的内心旅程。其结果是现代政治报道中的一项罕见壮举：在报道中，主题进行了真正的内省。罗姆尼花了数年时间为党内的极右分子扭曲自己，最终在 2012 年大选中成为共和党的旗手。在采访中，他谈到了多年来他所做的合理化解释，以及科平斯所说的“自我辩护的能力”。但当唐纳德·特朗普;赢得总统职位;时—— ——书名中的“清算”时刻——罗姆尼决定投入战斗。民粹主义和愤怒的力量已经压倒了共和党。问题是罗姆尼能否为自己找到救赎。

;

;《雅各书》告诫信徒要“行道，而不仅仅是听道”。书信解释说，没有“行为”，信心就是空的。然而，信仰在政治中变成作品的方式可能就像一个复杂的结，有很多褶皱。黑人福音派和白人福音派有着共同的神学信仰，但在党派关系上存在分歧。罗马天主教有着丰富的社会正义传统，但许多保守的天主教徒都是右翼的步兵。宗教提供了指南针，但不是地图。全民医疗保健？平衡预算？保护边境？圣经和其他宗教文本都是沉默的。人们可以确定广泛的原则——有时甚至这些原则是矛盾的——但具体的政策必须来自人类的智慧和流程。

;

;罗姆尼的流程来自另一个根深蒂固的身份：数据驱动的商人。十九世纪七十年代，罗姆尼从哈佛大学获得工商管理硕士和法学联合学位毕业后，开始在新兴的管理咨询领域工作。他最终加入了贝恩咨询公司。公司，他很快就成为明星。贝恩的领导层让他负责一家新的投资公司贝恩资本，该公司负责识别陷入困境的公司进行投资，从内部对其进行彻底改革，然后将其出售以获取利润。该公司让罗姆尼变得异常富有，并帮助他开启了政治生涯。这也影响了他在马萨诸塞州的执政，他在那里主要将自己视为“实用主义党派”，而不是空想家。他处理医疗保健问题的方法很能说明问题。 “我不会边看边说，‘保守派对此有何看法？’ “他告诉科平斯。 “我问，‘我认为某个特定问题的正确答案是什么？’当罗姆尼开始考虑竞选总统并向保守派观众推销自己时，他有一组新的数据点需要考虑。他将自己重塑为社会问题的斗士；他一生都是猎人，尽管他一生只打过两次猎；以及非法移民的狂热分子。罗姆尼很少考虑他的新形象的真实性。 “这是一个简单的数学问题，”科平斯写道。

;

;即使罗姆尼在树桩上重塑自己，他的信仰仍然存在。福音派基督徒是共和党初选中的一个重要投票群体，他们认为摩门教是异端。罗姆尼的一些支持者建议他远离自己的信仰。罗姆尼拒绝了。根据科平斯的说法，这可能是他一生中唯一拒绝妥协的部分。他在公共汽车上和辩论前祈祷，每天阅读圣经，并避免在安息日安排竞选活动。罗姆尼甚至安排教会的波士顿圣殿为他和家人举办深夜聚会，这是一次不同寻常的住宿。 “罗姆尼渴望在那些神圣的敬拜仪式中体验到与上帝的亲近，”科平斯写道。 “那天晚上，他把总统候选人的服装换成了圣殿里简单的白色服装，他感觉自己完全、真正地像自己了。”

;

;也许罗姆尼竞选中最激动人心的时刻是 2007 年 12 月 6 日，当时罗姆尼决定在德克萨斯州大学城的乔治·H·W·布什总统图书馆和博物馆发表演讲，直接解决人们对他信仰的担忧。 “我相信我的摩门教信仰，并努力以此为生，”他说。 “有些人认为，这样坦白我的信仰会导致我的候选资格失败。如果他们是对的，那就这样吧。但我认为他们低估了美国人民。美国人不尊重追求便利的人。美国人厌倦了那些为了赢得全世界而放弃信仰的人。”两个月后，罗姆尼的竞选活动结束。

;
;
;

;当决定是否参加 2012 年总统竞选时，罗姆尼内心很矛盾。媒体普遍认为他是共和党的领跑者，但他的大多数家人反对再次竞选。右翼正在经历转变。奥巴马担任总统期间，煽动了反建制的茶党运动，而共和党内躁动不安、充满怨恨的草根阶层似乎对罗姆尼这样的贵族人物并不特别热情。他还决心避免 2008 年的扭曲。“当然，我想获胜，但感觉我一直忠于我所相信的事情更为重要，”罗姆尼在给顾问的电子邮件中写道。;

;竞选活动决定持续关注经济；罗姆尼一直以一位扭亏为盈专家的身份来阐述自己的观点。但是，根据科平斯的说法，罗姆尼的顾问继续敦促他倾向极右翼。他关于移民的言论近乎本土主义。在一场共和党辩论中，他建议对无证移民进行“自我驱逐”。他还寻求特朗普的支持，特朗普花了几个月的时间煽动有关奥巴马出生地的毫无根据的阴谋论。罗姆尼获得提名，但在选举中被奥巴马击败。那天晚上，当他的一位顾问提出再次竞选的前景时，他坚称，“伙计们，我在舞台上的时间已经结束了。”

;

;罗姆尼在科平斯的书的第四章中第一次遇到唐纳德·特朗普。 1995 年，特朗普邀请罗姆尼到他位于海湖庄园的豪华庄园过周末。据科平斯说，罗姆尼觉得这次经历“非常奇怪”，并认为他再也见不到特朗普了。 2016 年提名竞赛期间，这位大亨在民意调查中的支持率上升让他感到困惑。 He and Ann watched Trump's rallies, where the spectre of violence seemed omnipresent. “那些人没有参加我们的活动，”安说。当特朗普可能赢得共和党提名的情况明朗时，罗姆尼急忙阻止他，发表演讲谴责他是“骗子”，后来又在幕后工作，将提名送交大会。他曾向朋友预测特朗普将赢得大选。即便如此，事情发生时他也毫无准备。

;
;
;

;然而，罗姆尼对特朗普的抵制并没有直线进行。众所周知，他曾考虑加入特朗普政府担任国务卿。当两人在纽约特朗普国际酒店大厦内的豪华餐厅 Jean-Georges 共进晚餐的照片在网上疯传时，这种反复无常的表情包又回来了。在橙黄色调的图像中，特朗普似乎几乎在咯咯笑。罗姆尼看起来很懊恼，眉毛扬起，嘴唇抿在一起。他后来向科平斯坚称，他的言论与特朗普无关。 “这与在公共餐厅里拍照的尴尬有关，”他说。晚宴结束后，他告诉记者，他“越来越希望当选总统特朗普能够带领我们走向更美好的未来”。据科平斯称，特朗普打电话给罗姆尼，告诉他需要发表更强硬的声明：特朗普“棒极了”，将成为“伟大的总统”。罗姆尼不能再忍受这种假装了。科平斯写道：“也许在多年来允许琐碎的侮辱和道德妥协堆积起来之后，他终于达到了极限。”

;

;科平斯详细描述了罗姆尼在特朗普上任的头几个月里日益增长的警惕性：旅行禁令;国务院人员外流；在夏洛茨维尔举行白人民族主义集会后发表的声明称，“双方都有非常优秀的人”。有一次，罗姆尼抄下了威廉·巴特勒·叶芝在第一次世界大战后写的诗《第二次来临》中的一句话：“最好的人缺乏所有信念，而最坏的人/充满激情。”这就是罗姆尼心目中的新共和党。 2017年秋天，他决定重返政坛，竞选犹他州参议员席位。 “当你没有钱的时候，当你年轻的时候，金钱是一种激励，”他在日记中写道。 “现在的动力就是比自我更伟大的目标。”这个目的是成为特朗普的制衡力量。

;

;在参议院，罗姆尼的地位和毅力似乎都在增长。在他竞选总统期间使他瘫痪的谨慎已经消失了。他成为党内少数愿意批评特朗普过激行为的人之一。 2019 年 12 月 18 日，众议院;投票弹劾;总统指控称他拒绝向乌克兰提供军事援助，以向乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基施压，要求其展开有利于特朗普政治的调查。为参议院的审判做准备，罗姆尼研究了《联邦党人文集》第 65 期，其中亚历山大·汉密尔顿认为，参议院是唯一具有足够独立性、能够以“必要的公正性”处理审判的机构。审判只持续了五天。

;

;罗姆尼对他的共和党同事感到沮丧。 “我们的核心小组与真正的陪审团有何不同？”他在日记中写道。一天晚上，参议院休会后，罗姆尼回到办公室，跪在地板上祈祷。后来，他在日记中列出了投票给特朗普定罪的潜在后果：他将在参议院受到排斥；福克斯新闻会对他进行猛烈抨击，“煽动人们的疯狂”；总统会无情地攻击他，或者利用政府来伤害他的儿子；罗姆尼可能需要离开犹他州。那天晚上，在他位于华盛顿的联排别墅里，他睡得很不好，黎明前就醒了，再次审查这个案子。在他的办公室里，他召集了员工，告诉他们他已经做出了裁决。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;2020 年 2 月 5 日，罗姆尼站在参议院议事厅的讲台上;解释了他决定;成为美国历史上第一位投票罢免总统脱离本党派的参议员。 “作为一名参议员兼陪审员，我在上帝面前发誓，要行使‘公正的正义’，”他说。 “我笃信宗教。我的信仰是我的核心。”说到这里，罗姆尼停顿了几秒钟，眼神低垂，似乎不知所措。 “我在上帝面前发誓，这具有重大意义，”他继续说道。他说，为了党派目的而无视这一誓言，将使他的性格受到“我自己良心的谴责”。他承认，他的政党和州内的许多人不同意这一决定。他还承认，他的投票不会让特朗普下台。 “我会告诉我的孩子和他们的孩子，我已尽我最大的能力履行了自己的职责，”他说，“相信我的国家对我有这样的期望。”演讲结束后，罗姆尼联系了安用电话。她将观看他的演讲描述为一种精神体验。在接下来的日子里，随着罗姆尼的尖酸刻薄，他想起了帕利·帕克·普拉特（Parley Parker Pratt），一位早期的摩门教传教士，也是一位远祖，他在纽约辛苦了几个月，却没有赢得任何皈依者，但有一天他看到了异象。主的保证——他的努力没有白费，他的牺牲已被接受。罗姆尼在日记中写道，巨大的负担已经解除，“焦虑消失了。”

;

;2021 年春天，科平斯和罗姆尼开始每周秘密会面，接受有时会进行的采访用了几个小时。自 1 月 6 日起义以来已经过去了几个月，科平斯写道，罗姆尼“听起来常常像敌后间谍”。罗姆尼坦言，他的政党中的大部分人“真的不相信宪法”。他正在思考一些棘手的问题，包括他自己对共和党的发展负有责任：“右翼的腐烂是新的，还是刚刚浮出水面的非常古老的东西？而主流建制派的成员——像他这样的人，;通情达理;的共和党人——在让这种腐烂恶化的过程中扮演了什么角色？”

;

;

;上个月，七十六岁的罗姆尼宣布，他不会寻求参议院连任。他在决定中提到了自己的年龄，并宣称是时候更换新一代领导人了。据科平斯称，罗姆尼一再有自己死亡的预感。他的教会教导他，有一天，他将站在上帝面前，面对他的思想、言语和行为的清算。他必须解释他的政治生涯——他所采取的立场、他所做的妥协以及他选择坚持的立场。如果罗姆尼不知所措，他可能会带来科平斯的计算记录。 ♦

;米特·罗姆尼 (Mitt Romney) 和他的家人聚集在一家经济型酒店房间内。现在是 2008 年 1 月，距离新罕布什尔州初选只有几天了。共和党总统提名候选人罗姆尼坐在高背椅上，穿着他惯用的盔甲：海军蓝色领带、带袖扣的闪亮白衬衫和正装裤。他的妻子安坐在他旁边。他的两个儿子和一个儿媳妇排列在他们周围。罗姆尼的竞选进展不顺利。他在爱荷华州党团会议中惨败给前阿肯色州州长迈克·赫卡比(Mike Huckabee)，而在新罕布什尔州，他似乎又会输给参议员约翰·麦凯恩(John McCain)。 “也许你再等几年？”罗姆尼的一个儿子建议道。罗姆尼似乎否认了这种可能性。 “当这一切结束后，我就会建立一个品牌，”他说。 “人们会认识我的。他们会知道我的立场。”他停了下来。 “狂妄的摩门教，”他说道，脸上露出半微笑。他的家人发出一些窃笑声，更多的是沮丧而不是有趣。随后，族人跪在地上祈祷。罗姆尼低下头，手肘撑在椅子上。安在祈祷中感谢上帝的祝福，并表示全家只想“为您服务，为这个地球带来更大的光明。”

;

;这一刻被 2014 年的纪录片《Mitt》捕捉到，概括了;米特·罗姆尼;的持久悖论。在马萨诸塞州担任温和派州长后，他的标志性成就是颁布了全民医疗保健制度，在两次失败的总统竞选期间，他在意识形态和语气上进行了转变，以引导他的政党的右倾倾向。他从未摆脱过关于他是一个反复无常、缺乏真正信念的人的诽谤。 2008 年，在新罕布什尔州举行的;共和党候选人论坛;期间，麦凯恩转向罗姆尼说：“我们在很多问题上存在分歧，但我同意你是变革的候选人。”在竞选活动中，罗姆尼常常给人一种笔挺、僵硬的印象，就像他熨烫得干脆的正装衬衫一样。选民们很难真正了解他。然而，对于那些进入他的世界的人来说，他的核心始终是显而易见的。这在新罕布什尔州的酒店房间中很明显，在麦凯·科平斯的启发性新传记中也很明显，“;罗姆尼：清算;”，其中这位政治家的摩门教信仰成为滋养他生活中其他一切的基础。

;科平斯和《米特》的导演格雷格·怀特利都是耶稣基督后期圣徒教会的成员，这绝非偶然。科平斯依靠对罗姆尼的数十次采访以及数百页的个人日记和私人信件，讲述了罗姆尼的野心和原则日益陷入冲突时的内心旅程。其结果是现代政治报道中的一项罕见壮举：在报道中，主题进行了真正的内省。罗姆尼花了数年时间为党内的极右分子扭曲自己，最终在 2012 年大选中成为共和党的旗手。在采访中，他谈到了多年来他所做的合理化解释，以及科平斯所说的“自我辩护的能力”。但当唐纳德·特朗普;赢得总统职位;时—— ——书名中的“清算”时刻——罗姆尼决定投入战斗。民粹主义和愤怒的力量已经压倒了共和党。问题是罗姆尼能否为自己找到救赎。

;

;《雅各书》告诫信徒要“行道，而不仅仅是听道”。书信解释说，没有“行为”，信心就是空的。然而，信仰在政治中变成作品的方式可能就像一个复杂的结，有很多褶皱。黑人福音派和白人福音派有着共同的神学信仰，但在党派关系上存在分歧。罗马天主教有着丰富的社会正义传统，但许多保守的天主教徒都是右翼的步兵。宗教提供了指南针，但不是地图。全民医疗保健？平衡预算？保护边境？圣经和其他宗教文本都是沉默的。人们可以确定广泛的原则——有时甚至这些原则是矛盾的——但具体的政策必须来自人类的智慧和流程。

;

;罗姆尼的流程来自另一个根深蒂固的身份：数据驱动的商人。十九世纪七十年代，罗姆尼从哈佛大学获得工商管理硕士和法学联合学位毕业后，开始在新兴的管理咨询领域工作。他最终加入了贝恩咨询公司。公司，他很快就成为明星。贝恩的领导层让他负责一家新的投资公司贝恩资本，该公司负责识别陷入困境的公司进行投资，从内部对其进行彻底改革，然后将其出售以获取利润。该公司让罗姆尼变得异常富有，并帮助他开启了政治生涯。这也影响了他在马萨诸塞州的执政，他在那里主要将自己视为“实用主义党派”，而不是空想家。他处理医疗保健问题的方法很能说明问题。 “我不会边看边说，‘保守派对此有何看法？’ “他告诉科平斯。 “我问，‘我认为某个特定问题的正确答案是什么？’当罗姆尼开始考虑竞选总统并向保守派观众推销自己时，他有一组新的数据点需要考虑。他将自己重塑为社会问题的斗士；他一生都是猎人，尽管他一生只打过两次猎；以及非法移民的狂热分子。罗姆尼很少考虑他的新形象的真实性。 “这是一个简单的数学问题，”科平斯写道。

;

;即使罗姆尼在树桩上重塑自己，他的信仰仍然存在。福音派基督徒是共和党初选中的一个重要投票群体，他们认为摩门教是异端。罗姆尼的一些支持者建议他远离自己的信仰。罗姆尼拒绝了。根据科平斯的说法，这可能是他一生中唯一拒绝妥协的部分。他在公共汽车上和辩论前祈祷，每天阅读圣经，并避免在安息日安排竞选活动。罗姆尼甚至安排教会的波士顿圣殿为他和家人举办深夜聚会，这是一次不同寻常的住宿。 “罗姆尼渴望在那些神圣的敬拜仪式中体验到与上帝的亲近，”科平斯写道。 “那天晚上，他把总统候选人的服装换成了圣殿里简单的白色服装，他感觉自己完全、真正地像自己了。”

;

;也许罗姆尼竞选中最激动人心的时刻是 2007 年 12 月 6 日，当时罗姆尼决定在德克萨斯州大学城的乔治·H·W·布什总统图书馆和博物馆发表演讲，直接解决人们对他信仰的担忧。 “我相信我的摩门教信仰，并努力以此为生，”他说。 “有些人认为，这样坦白我的信仰会导致我的候选资格失败。如果他们是对的，那就这样吧。但我认为他们低估了美国人民。美国人不尊重追求便利的人。美国人厌倦了那些为了赢得全世界而放弃信仰的人。”两个月后，罗姆尼的竞选活动结束。

;
;
;

;当决定是否参加 2012 年总统竞选时，罗姆尼内心很矛盾。媒体普遍认为他是共和党的领跑者，但他的大多数家人反对再次竞选。右翼正在经历转变。奥巴马担任总统期间，煽动了反建制的茶党运动，而共和党内躁动不安、充满怨恨的草根阶层似乎对罗姆尼这样的贵族人物并不特别热情。他还决心避免 2008 年的扭曲。“当然，我想获胜，但感觉我一直忠于我所相信的事情更为重要，”罗姆尼在给顾问的电子邮件中写道。;

;竞选活动决定持续关注经济；罗姆尼一直以一位扭亏为盈专家的身份来阐述自己的观点。但是，根据科平斯的说法，罗姆尼的顾问继续敦促他倾向极右翼。他关于移民的言论近乎本土主义。在一场共和党辩论中，他建议对无证移民进行“自我驱逐”。他还寻求特朗普的支持，特朗普花了几个月的时间煽动有关奥巴马出生地的毫无根据的阴谋论。罗姆尼获得提名，但在选举中被奥巴马击败。那天晚上，当他的一位顾问提出再次竞选的前景时，他坚称，“伙计们，我在舞台上的时间已经结束了。”

;

;罗姆尼在科平斯的书的第四章中第一次遇到唐纳德·特朗普。 1995 年，特朗普邀请罗姆尼到他位于海湖庄园的豪华庄园过周末。据科平斯说，罗姆尼觉得这次经历“非常奇怪”，并认为他再也见不到特朗普了。 2016 年提名竞赛期间，这位大亨在民意调查中的支持率上升让他感到困惑。 He and Ann watched Trump's rallies, where the spectre of violence seemed omnipresent. “那些人没有参加我们的活动，”安说。当特朗普可能赢得共和党提名的情况明朗时，罗姆尼急忙阻止他，发表演讲谴责他是“骗子”，后来又在幕后工作，将提名送交大会。他曾向朋友预测特朗普将赢得大选。即便如此，事情发生时他也毫无准备。

;
;
;

;然而，罗姆尼对特朗普的抵制并没有直线进行。众所周知，他曾考虑加入特朗普政府担任国务卿。当两人在纽约特朗普国际酒店大厦内的豪华餐厅 Jean-Georges 共进晚餐的照片在网上疯传时，这种反复无常的表情包又回来了。在橙黄色调的图像中，特朗普似乎几乎在咯咯笑。罗姆尼看起来很懊恼，眉毛扬起，嘴唇抿在一起。他后来向科平斯坚称，他的言论与特朗普无关。 “这与在公共餐厅里拍照的尴尬有关，”他说。晚宴结束后，他告诉记者，他“越来越希望当选总统特朗普能够带领我们走向更美好的未来”。据科平斯称，特朗普打电话给罗姆尼，告诉他需要发表更强硬的声明：特朗普“棒极了”，将成为“伟大的总统”。罗姆尼不能再忍受这种假装了。科平斯写道：“也许在多年来允许琐碎的侮辱和道德妥协堆积起来之后，他终于达到了极限。”

;

;科平斯详细描述了罗姆尼在特朗普上任的头几个月里日益增长的警惕性：旅行禁令;国务院人员外流；在夏洛茨维尔举行白人民族主义集会后发表的声明称，“双方都有非常优秀的人”。有一次，罗姆尼抄下了威廉·巴特勒·叶芝在第一次世界大战后写的诗《第二次来临》中的一句话：“最好的人缺乏所有信念，而最坏的人/充满激情。”这就是罗姆尼心目中的新共和党。 2017年秋天，他决定重返政坛，竞选犹他州参议员席位。 “当你没有钱的时候，当你年轻的时候，金钱是一种激励，”他在日记中写道。 “现在的动力就是比自我更伟大的目标。”这个目的是成为特朗普的制衡力量。

;

;在参议院，罗姆尼的地位和毅力似乎都在增长。在他竞选总统期间使他瘫痪的谨慎已经消失了。他成为党内少数愿意批评特朗普过激行为的人之一。 2019 年 12 月 18 日，众议院;投票弹劾;总统指控称他拒绝向乌克兰提供军事援助，以向乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基施压，要求其展开有利于特朗普政治的调查。为参议院的审判做准备，罗姆尼研究了《联邦党人文集》第 65 期，其中亚历山大·汉密尔顿认为，参议院是唯一具有足够独立性、能够以“必要的公正性”处理审判的机构。审判只持续了五天。

;

;罗姆尼对他的共和党同事感到沮丧。 “我们的核心小组与真正的陪审团有何不同？”他在日记中写道。一天晚上，参议院休会后，罗姆尼回到办公室，跪在地板上祈祷。后来，他在日记中列出了投票给特朗普定罪的潜在后果：他将在参议院受到排斥；福克斯新闻会对他进行猛烈抨击，“煽动人们的疯狂”；总统会无情地攻击他，或者利用政府来伤害他的儿子；罗姆尼可能需要离开犹他州。那天晚上，在他位于华盛顿的联排别墅里，他睡得很不好，黎明前就醒了，再次审查这个案子。在他的办公室里，他召集了员工，告诉他们他已经做出了裁决。

;

;
;
;
;

;2020 年 2 月 5 日，罗姆尼站在参议院议事厅的讲台上;解释了他决定;成为美国历史上第一位投票罢免总统脱离本党派的参议员。 “作为一名参议员兼陪审员，我在上帝面前发誓，要行使‘公正的正义’，”他说。 “我笃信宗教。我的信仰是我的核心。”说到这里，罗姆尼停顿了几秒钟，眼神低垂，似乎不知所措。 “我在上帝面前发誓，这具有重大意义，”他继续说道。他说，为了党派目的而无视这一誓言，将使他的性格受到“我自己良心的谴责”。他承认，他的政党和州内的许多人不同意这一决定。他还承认，他的投票不会让特朗普下台。 “我会告诉我的孩子和他们的孩子，我已尽我最大的能力履行了自己的职责，”他说，“相信我的国家对我有这样的期望。”演讲结束后，罗姆尼联系了安用电话。她将观看他的演讲描述为一种精神体验。在接下来的日子里，随着罗姆尼的尖酸刻薄，他想起了帕利·帕克·普拉特（Parley Parker Pratt），一位早期的摩门教传教士，也是一位远祖，他在纽约辛苦了几个月，却没有赢得任何皈依者，但有一天他看到了异象。主的保证——他的努力没有白费，他的牺牲已被接受。罗姆尼在日记中写道，巨大的负担已经解除，“焦虑消失了。”

;

;2021 年春天，科平斯和罗姆尼开始每周秘密会面，接受有时会进行的采访用了几个小时。自 1 月 6 日起义以来已经过去了几个月，科平斯写道，罗姆尼“听起来常常像敌后间谍”。罗姆尼坦言，他的政党中的大部分人“真的不相信宪法”。他正在思考一些棘手的问题，包括他自己对共和党的发展负有责任：“右翼的腐烂是新的，还是刚刚浮出水面的非常古老的东西？而主流建制派的成员——像他这样的人，;通情达理;的共和党人——在让这种腐烂恶化的过程中扮演了什么角色？”

;
;
;

;上个月，七十六岁的罗姆尼宣布，他不会寻求参议院连任。他在决定中提到了自己的年龄，并宣称是时候更换新一代领导人了。据科平斯称，罗姆尼一再有自己死亡的预感。他的教会教导他，有一天，他将站在上帝面前，面对他的思想、言语和行为的清算。他必须解释他的政治生涯——他所采取的立场、他所做的妥协以及他选择坚持的立场。如果罗姆尼不知所措，他可能会带来科平斯的计算记录。 ♦

;在整个联盟出现多个交易请求的休赛期之后，篮球赛季即将到来。 NBA 请求交易的传统方式是球员或其代表与球队管理层进行谈判。但 2022 年就是这样了。是时候发挥创意，让您的交易请求像病毒一样传播开来了。把它当作一场舞会。向您的团队表明您是认真的。以下是球员可以用来让自己穿上新球队制服的一些交易请求想法，统计数据。

;

;;退役，然后再退役;

;

;没有人愿意打电话它退出了。但如果你想让你的球队知道你永远不会再为他们效力，那就挂上球衣吧。退出你喜爱的游戏。你的合同将无效。然后静坐一年，然后发现——天哪！——你改变了主意。当你二十二岁退役时，你只需要从比赛中休息一下。好好休息后，二十三岁回来，与你原本想交易的球队签约。这是一个大胆的举动，可能会让您损失数百万美元，但想想您将不得不一直玩电子游戏！

;

;;在另一支球队的竞技场前扎营;

;

;露营将表明您有多么致力于改变自己的处境。假设这是 iPhone 版本。准备一个帐篷和一些瓶装水，然后在所需团队的总部前面开设商店。你是一名 NBA 球员，这意味着你的身高和名气足以吸引人们的注意。你不会孤单，因为媒体和粉丝会和你一起出去玩。您甚至可能会在进入大楼的路上遇到您想要的团队的经理，并将您的简历交给他。

;

;;纹身您的交易请求;

;
;
;

;将您的交易请求写在身上。每个人都会看着你想，他一定很讨厌他所在的球队；另外，我想知道纹身师是谁——他们做得很棒！把它放在你的前臂或脸上，或者两者兼而有之——这将是不可避免的，而且对于你当前的团队成员来说，每当他们看到你时，事情都会变得非常尴尬。当他们问“你好吗？”时，你只需指着你的纹身即可。一旦你被交易，请去除纹身，并为你准备好请求另一次交易腾出空间。

;

;;向泰勒·斯威夫特支付费用以发布你的交易请求;;

;如果您希望自己的事业得到关注，请向泰勒·斯威夫特寻求帮助。无论她发布什么内容，Swifties 都会团结起来。泰勒将你的交易请求发布到她的 Instagram 故事上二十四小时，这将改变你未来几年的生活。如果她标记团队主席，他将无法处理数以百万计的 Swifties 向他的社交媒体帐户发送垃圾邮件。他不想在 Swifties 不利的一方待太久。这种社会耻辱是难以克服的。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;获得一款签名鞋;

;

;拥有自己的运动鞋的玩家会出于各种不同的原因发布特别版本。例如，迈克尔·乔丹 (Michael Jordan) 出售“流感游戏”版的鞋子，因为他在 NBA 总决赛期间带病打球时穿着这双鞋。为您的签名鞋制作一个特殊的配色，称为“Trade Request”版或“Get Me Out of Town”版。颜色？显然它们必须是你想效力的球队的颜色。拍摄一个由斯派克·李主演的很酷的广告，这样当你最终被交易时，人们就会说，“一定是鞋子！”

;

;;举办一个派对，只邀请来自不同球队的球员;

;

;每个人都喜欢精彩的聚会。他们不喜欢的是不被邀请。举办一场聚会，只邀请您想效力的球队中的球员。不要邀请你现在的队友。聚会结束后的第二天，在社交媒体上发布聚会的照片。当你的队友看到他们错过的所有乐趣时，比如香槟喷泉、杂技杂耍和激烈的叠叠乐游戏，他们会感到被冒犯。他们会非常生气，再也不会把球传给你，从而迫使管理层确保你尽快离开球队。

;

;;从家里得到一张便条;;

;
;

;父母或监护人的便条的力量被低估了。仅仅因为你不再是孩子，并不意味着你父母形象的权威就不那么重要了。让你妈妈给球队主席写一封简短的便条，说：“我的儿子不再被允许为你的球队效力，因为我们有顾虑。”繁荣——问题解决了。什么样的球队主席不会听取球员妈妈的担忧？

;
;
;

;;从你的医生那里得到一张便条;

;<如果那个无情的球队主席不理会家里的便条，你就必须用医生的便条提高赌注。让你的医生解释为什么你因身体原因不能再为球队效力，并且必须迅速被交易到新球队。这是一个需要解决的严峻形势。你的团队主席有义务倾听科学。从你的医生那里得到这张单子，你很快就会被派到一个新的团队开始治疗过程。 ♦

;纽黑文绿地 (New Haven Green) 是一座 17 世纪的公园，一侧毗邻法院大楼和朴素的政府办公室，包括纽黑文市政厅独特的条纹外观。对面是耶鲁大学豪华的哥特式建筑，这是常春藤盟校，拥有四百亿美元的捐赠。平衡城镇和大学的利益在很大程度上取决于纽黑文奥尔德斯委员会，这是一个由三十名成员组成的委员会。董事会每月召开两次会议，出席的桤木成员通常比公众多得多。但在二月初，在市政厅二楼举行的一次会议上，桤木数量处于劣势。人群挤在长椅上，沿着后墙站立，聆听市长贾斯汀·埃利克 (Justin Elicker) 发表年度市情咨文。

;

;身着深蓝色西装、身材瘦长的耶鲁大学校友埃利克 (Justin Elicker) 宣称纽黑文在经历了大流行病低迷和六千六百万美元的预算赤字后，“表现优于整个州和所有其他主要城市”。尽管中位家庭的收入仍然约为四万九千美元，四分之一的居民生活在联邦贫困线或以下，但复苏是真实的。耶鲁大学是该市最大的土地所有者，是一家非营利组织，因此无需缴纳学校财产税。 （耶鲁大学和耶鲁纽黑文医院的总税收减免将涵盖该市的大部分教育预算。）1990年，该大学开始每年自愿付款，通常只是象征性地支付其所欠费用的一小部分。埃里克解释说，事情开始发生变化。他说，到 2022 年，“我们将耶鲁大学的年度自愿捐款几乎增加了一倍，从 1300 万美元增加到 2300 万美元”。据市长说，原因之一是？ “Decades of grassroots organizing by ;Unite Here;.”

;

;;Unite Here; is a North American labor union, with roots in the garment and hotel trades, that's known for its willingness to strike. Its divisions in New Haven have grown to encompass some eight thousand people who work at Yale. The earliest effort began in 1941, with Local 35, when mechanics in the campus power plant organized and later fought to bring in custodial and dining-hall workers. In 1984, the union struck for ten weeks to support receptionists, librarians, and laboratory researchers in their formation of Local 34. Most recently, after several failed attempts stretching across more than three decades, graduate-student teachers finally won their own union, Local 33.

;

;The mayor credited the unions for holding the university accountable, but the gesture was also politically expedient: the Board of Alders is dominated by members or allies of ;Unite Here;. In a 2011 campaign nicknamed Aldermania, the unions ran a slate of candidates to win a majority on the Board. The idea was to bring working-class residents into government and turn the board into more than a rubber-stamping mechanism for the mayor. Weeks of door-knocking during the sticky summer heat paid off: seventeen of eighteen candidates endorsed by the union won their elections. They were Black and white and Latino; there was a Yale janitor, a Yale library assistant, and a Yale undergraduate. The majority has held ever since.

;

;Tyisha Walker-Myers, who became an alder in the 2011 election, is now in her fourth term as president of the board. During the State of the City address, she sat to the right of Elicker, wearing glasses and long braids. She grew up in West River, a predominantly Black neighborhood, as factories in the area were shrivelling. She attended Albertus Magnus College, a local Roman Catholic university in New Haven, but felt out of place—“I was the only minority”—and left without a degree. In 1998, she got a job in a dining hall at Yale, her first real experience of the university beyond the monied shadow that it cast over her home town. “If you came on campus and weren't supposed to be there, you were going to be chased out by security,” she recalled. She became a shop steward in Local 35, then took a full-time job at the union. Her jump into local politics—the alder gig was technically part time and came with a tiny stipend—still felt like an odd fit. “People believe politics is crooked,” she said. “I'm not a politician because I don't lie. I'm very straightforward.”

;

;Across the country, ;Unite Here; invests heavily in electoral politics. One of its locals, the ;Culinary Union;, in Las Vegas, has played a big role in keeping Nevada blue. In California, María Elena Durazo, a former ;Unite Here; organizer, is a powerful member of the California Senate and has served as vice-chair of the Democratic National Committee. But it is in New Haven that the union has come closest to functioning like an actual political party. The Yale locals' effort to put members in office was part of a larger mission to bridge New Haven's town-gown divide.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It was a daunting, aspirational program: to jumble the boundaries of race and class and élite education. Some experiences would never be shared. In Elicker's speech, he arrived at the topic of gun violence. It was just a month into the new year, and five residents of New Haven, which has a population of a hundred and thirty-nine thousand, had already been killed—all people of color. (White people make up about forty per cent of New Haven; the rest are mostly Black or Latino.) The first victim, Dontae Myers, was twenty-three when he was shot, on New Year's Day. His brother, Dashown, had been killed in similar circumstances, in 2020—and a community group started by ;Unite Here;, called New Haven Rising, organized vigils after both of their deaths. The boys' mother, LaQuvia Jones, was Walker-Myers's best friend, as close to her as a sister. The mayor paraphrased something that Jones had said: “When you pull the trigger, you don't pull it on a target. You pull it on a community. You pull it on anyone who loves that person.”

;
;
;

;In January, the planning for Dontae's funeral had awkwardly coincided with celebrations at the union. A few blocks from city hall, grad students in jeans and shabby-chic sweaters were gathered in the basement of a Methodist church, which rents space to the union, to watch a live feed of the National Labor Relations Board certifying ballots for and against Local 33. The viewing party was largely devoid of suspense (the yes vote was overwhelming), but the room still whooped when the union was proclaimed official. There was a feeling of resolution. At the same time, the result would test the durability of the ;Unite Here; model. Graduate workers had built their demands on the struggles of Locals 35 and 34: New Haven's working class. These fellow-unionists expected fealty to labor—and to the needs of the city's residents—over Yale. It was more than a decade into Aldermania, which was now a mature political experiment in a stubbornly unequal place. Could the Yale unions find enough common ground between graduate students and custodians and billing clerks to keep the experiment going?

;

;The town-gown divide is almost as old as the college town itself. In a fabled instance from the mid-fourteenth century, students at Oxford accused the owners of the Swindlestock Tavern of serving subpar alcohol. Townies came to the tavern's defense, and the conflict erupted into a three-day riot that killed nearly a hundred men. Much later, the US imported many aspects of the physically and socially cloistered British university system. Town-gown relations proved manageable when the college was just one piece of the local economy. The strain sharpened when cities that once boomed with manufacturing became overly dependent on higher education.

;

;By the seventies and eighties, New Haven's factories were shutting down. Workers turned to jobs in health care and the service sector, and Yale became one of the city's top employers. (Its sister corporation, Yale New Haven Health System, is the largest private employer in Connecticut.) Yale expanded in enrollment and physical size, and its endowment grew at a rate that's difficult to comprehend, doubling since the Great Recession. New Haven, meanwhile, stayed relatively poor: the nonprofit DataHaven found that between 1990 and 2017—a span of nearly thirty years—the median household income ;decreased; by about two thousand dollars. Four-fifths of higher-wage jobs are held by suburban commuters who don't live in the city.

;
;
;

;Yale made some efforts to be a good neighbor: it set up an Office of New Haven Affairs, redeveloped a commercial corridor downtown, and established a first-time-home-buyer subsidy for university employees, many of whom came from the surrounding community. Still, the Yale unions saw a need for more ambitious redistribution. They pushed initiatives that had little to do with contracts or other typical union fare, provoking accusations of “machine politics” and undue influence from their critics. “This particular vision of industrial unionism is pretty unique and not something you see very much at other unionized institutions of higher ed,” Zach Schwartz-Weinstein, a historian of Local 35 and a former member of NYU's grad-worker union, told me.

;

;The unions pressured Yale to deliver more voluntary payments to the city and scrutinized Yale's requests for building permits. They established a local-hiring program run in partnership with the university, which, in 2015, promised to hire a thousand residents from New Haven, half from majority-minority “neighborhoods of need,” within five years. When Yale failed to keep pace, the Board of Alders convened a hearing that overflowed the aldermanic chambers. Walker-Myers, the board president, accused Yale of inflating its statistics with short-term construction jobs. A university representative promised to “think of systemic changes” to reach its goal. (In 2021, that goal was met.)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Part of ;Unite Here;'s strategy has been to recruit organizers from the Yale student body. In 1969, it brought on John Wilhelm, who had been a working-class transfer student and civil-rights activist. At the time, Local 35 was staging long, aggressive strikes to win better-than-poverty wages. Wilhelm believed that a union should be run mostly by workers from the rank and file—his mentor was Vincent Sirabella, a former waiter and bartender who'd risen through a local in Providence—but he also saw a place for intellectuals. In 2000, the union recruited Gwen Mills, a Cornell graduate who had grown up in New Haven. Mills helped to develop the campaign to run a labor slate for the Board of Alders. Like Wilhelm, she was later promoted to an executive position at the international headquarters of ;Unite Here;. They prototyped a career path that dozens of Yalies would follow.

;

;In April, Wilhelm and Mills flew to New Haven for a two-day celebration of Local 33's win. Former Ph.D. students, many now tenured professors, arrived from across the US, England, and Brazil, and gathered in the sanctuary of the Methodist church. Mills stood at the pulpit and described her transition from Yale-resenting townie to union organizer. “I grew up a mile from here,” she said. “I got married here in this sanctuary.” She recalled a popular bumper sticker from her childhood—“Beep! Beep! Yale's cheap!”—that critiqued the university's stingy approach to the community. New Haven, she said, is a “post-industrial manufacturing town with a multibillion-dollar education corporation plopped right into the middle of it.”

;

;I came to Yale as a college freshman in the late nineteen-nineties, naïve and unprepared. I'd never spent time on the East Coast. I was lousy at research and writing. I hadn't known anyone with money. When I tried to make small talk and asked one girl where she was from, she said, “Chelsea.” Another prep-school kid responded, “Park Avenue.” Where? Meanwhile, the message from Yale was to stay on campus, away from what it deemed the inner-city dangers of New Haven. I felt a small crack in this wall of alienation when I learned about the efforts of ;GESO;, the Graduate Employees and Students Organization, the precursor of Local 33.

;

;Looking back, it was risky for Locals 35 and 34 to ask dining-hall cooks and library aides—who lived in the neighborhoods I was told to avoid—to put their dues money toward a union for young classics scholars, let alone chemists who could seemingly go on to lucrative jobs in Big Pharma. Barbara Vereen, a Local 34 staffer who worked in medical billing at the time and was raised in New Haven, told me that she was initially dismissive of the graduate campaign. Then, in 2003, she heard a presentation on the tenure-track system. “I came back, and I told my co-workers, we're looking at this all wrong,” she said. “Like, these people are workers. They got the same problems that we got.” The Yale historian Michael Denning told me, “The struggle for the first ten or fifteen years was to see the teaching work of graduate students ;as work;. I wrote two or three essays to prove it to myself.”

;
;
;

;More persuasion came from Yale. Members of ;GESO; from the nineties and two-thousands endured years of acrimonious dealings. Even in departments that might have seemed friendly to unionization, student organizers say that they were sidelined, even blacklisted. “In anthropology, it was trench warfare,” Nazima Kadir, who was a Ph.D. student in that department, told me. One of her classmates was nearly expelled. An associate professor who came out in support of them was denied tenure. That professor was ;David Graeber;, who went on to teach in England and helped launch Occupy Wall Street. (According to Yale, the vast majority of professors in Graeber's cohort were denied tenure; the university maintains that it has respected the right to organize.)

;

;In the two-thousands, as colleges relied increasingly on Ph.D. and master's candidates to fill their teaching needs, graduate students across the US turned to unions. But, at private universities, the status of this workforce was unsettled: were they student-apprentices or true employees who deserved the right to organize? The National Labor Relations Board went back and forth on this question. In 2016, Local 33 unionized a few select departments; in 2017, members staged a hunger strike. Then, after the Trump years, the union relaunched a comprehensive drive. In the fall of 2022, organizers collected more than two thousand union cards, and, unlike in years past, Yale administrators and faculty mostly left the students alone.

;

;Local 33's victory this year was one of many landslide academic elections in a matter of months. At Boston University, the union won ninety-eight per cent of the vote; at the University of Chicago, ninety-two per cent; at the University of Minnesota, where the first attempt at a union had been made in 1974, ninety-seven per cent; at Duke, eighty-eight per cent. Late last year, nearly fifty thousand graduate teachers and researchers at the University of California struck for six weeks—the largest academic work stoppage in US history. A few months later, some nine thousand academic workers at Rutgers walked out over an expired contract. Only at Yale were grad workers integrated into a larger campus union, but the Rutgers campaign made a point of emphasizing links to the community. Its “common good” demands included a rent freeze on all Rutgers-owned properties and a million-dollar investment in the surrounding neighborhoods—though it won neither at the negotiating table. (Rutgers did promise to distribute six hundred thousand dollars through a nonprofit.)

;

;

;
;
;

;Since the beginning of 2022, the National Labor Relations Board has certified twenty-seven bargaining units at private colleges and universities, comprising more than thirty-two thousand student workers. Undergraduates with on-campus jobs have organized as well—at Dartmouth, the University of Pennsylvania, Barnard, Tufts, and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Some nineteen thousand student workers on the twenty-three campuses of the California State University system will soon vote in a union election. Colin Culver, an undergraduate at San Diego State University, told me that the majority are from working-class families in town. The school pays them less than they pay regular staff. “They use student staff to lower wages for everyone,” Culver said. The union, he hopes, will put a stop to that.

;

;This spring, I met with Sulema Hamilton, a custodian in Local 35, who had just finished her shift at Yale's Asian American Cultural Center. (I worked there senior year as part of my financial-aid package.) The center is situated in an old three-story brick building with a covered porch. Hamilton was dressed in her Yale navy blues and safety shoes, and wore sparkly earrings. When she was growing up in New Haven, she said, her grandmother worked at a gun plant and belonged to a union. Hamilton went away for college, then returned to marry and raise two daughters and a son. For many years, she was a bank teller, but after a while her career stalled. She knew that jobs at Yale were union, and asked about a clerical position, envisioning something at a desk. The recruiter pointed her in another direction. “She's, like, 'It could be the kitchen, or custodial services,' ” Hamilton told me. “I said, 'Well, I do all those things at home—how difficult can it be?' ” She did have one very grimy assignment—at Gryphon's Pub, in a Yale-owned property that smelled like beer and piss. “I made it look like a palace,” she said. “I never looked at my position as 'I'm doing something less.' ” Her janitorial pay and benefits soon surpassed what she had earned as a teller.

;

;Hamilton saw herself as a fixer of ordinary troubles, the kind of person you'd want to be around if anything bad came your way: unpaid overtime, improper orders, a nasty supervisor. She and other campus workers I interviewed described union membership in broader terms as well. “If you think about a big institution, a big establishment, you have to get into politics,” Lisa Stevens, a medical assistant at Yale's cancer center and the vice-president of Local 34, told me. “You have to find other ways to fight. We can never match their dollars.”

;

;In 2022, Hamilton took time off to canvass for Democratic Senate candidates in Pennsylvania and Georgia. Other members of Locals 35 and 34, and grad workers with Local 33, joined her. It wasn't unusual for unions to stump for Democratic politicians. But, in 2020, Gwen Mills, the New Haven townie at ;Unite Here;'s headquarters, devised a mass mobilization that doubled as income replacement. Most ;Unite Here; members worked in hotels and hospitality, and had lost their jobs during the pandemic. The union offered them hourly door-knocking work in battleground states—and helped pull off white-knuckle wins in Arizona, Pennsylvania, and Georgia (though Local 11, which covers Arizona and Southern California, later seemed to regret their exertions on behalf of now Senator Kyrsten Sinema).

;

;When ;GESO; got started, in the nineties, graduate unions were considered faddish and economically unnecessary: the purview of gender-studies scholars or Marxist students whose parents were Marxist professors. ;STEM; people were assumed to be hard to organize. Ditto international students. It's now harder to conjure a typical profile. At the vote count, in the church basement, I noticed a South Asian woman wearing a cut-up T-shirt covered in “Local 33 ;UNITEHERE;!” buttons, in the style of chain mail, that jangled as she moved around the room. Her name was Arita Acharya, and she had taken a leave of absence from her Ph.D. in genetics to work for the union. “Some of the reasons I went into ;STEM; were my real desire and curiosity, but it was also my culture hammering into me that this was the only worthy thing to do,” she told me. During the pandemic, she'd canvassed New Haven to try to get people vaccinated, and discovered that organizing was “another thing I might want.”

;

;Former organizers told me that ;Unite Here;'s expectations were “psychotic” and that the experience was “exhausting.” They also said that it changed their lives. Shana Redmond, now an English professor at Columbia, was part of a ;GESO; effort to pressure Yale to divest from private-prison companies. As “the child of a formerly incarcerated person,” she told me, she saw in that campaign “the possibility of what a union could be.” Redmond chose to stay in academia, but other organizers applied their Ph.Ds to careers in labor. At the Local 33 celebrations in April, alumni included the presidents of ;Unite Here; locals in Miami and Seattle, a labor educator in Massachusetts, and a labor strategist in Arizona. The Yale-to-union pipeline spawned a semi-facetious conspiracy theory: maybe ;Unite Here; had intentionally stretched out the graduate-student organizing, in order to recruit as many smart young people into the labor movement as possible.

;
;
;

;By late spring, Acharya was weighing this choice herself. “It's a scary moment right now,” she told me. Would she return to her lab in the fall or defect for a union job? She ultimately chose an option in between, extending her leave of absence—“Because I'm still having a good time!” she texted me. Other leaders of Local 33 resumed their studies. Abigail Fields, a Ph.D. candidate in French who'd been on leave with Acharya, went back to her dissertation on representations of agriculture and rural life in the nineteenth-century French novel. Fields would spend the coming year in France, but planned to stay involved in the union. Her immersion in organizing had changed her personality. “I like myself much more now than when I was keeping my head down,” she said. “My adviser also noticed a move in my dissertation from ecology to labor.”

;

;When campus emptied out for the summer, Acharya stayed busy with collective bargaining—Local 33 was meeting regularly with university representatives—and other ;Unite Here; business. The summer agenda was to tell neighbors about a new law that allowed renters to form tenants' unions, and encourage them to file complaints with the city's Fair Rent Commission. In June, the members of New Haven's first two tenants' unions rallied outside the offices of their corporate landlord. One protester held up a sign that said “A 30% Rent Increase Is a Soft Eviction!!!” Another described “a lot of mice, just killing them constantly.” In late August, after sixteen households in one of those buildings were given eviction notices, the statewide Connecticut Tenants Union (whose founders include members of Local 33) filed a lawsuit and called for a mass protest. The Yale unions showed up with hundreds of other people. Two days later, the company cancelled the evictions and agreed to negotiate.

;

;Luke Melonakos-Harrison, the vice-president of the Connecticut Tenants Union, graduated earlier this year from Yale's Divinity School. “I had some anxiety when I got into organizing as a Yale student, trying to get involved in New Haven,” he told me. “There's definitely tension there, and bad histories.” There were also commonalities. When he and his wife rented their first apartment in New Haven, the bathroom ceiling nearly crashed down on their heads—and the rent wasn't cheap. “Everyone's rent is going up and everyone hates their landlord,” Acharya said. While door-knocking three days a week, she found that housing issues got people talking, which she could use to segue into conversations about politics. A primary election was coming up, and the Yale unions had endorsed Elicker for a second term and twenty-two candidates for alder seats. Three of those alder candidates were running for the first time. A handful of others—including the fourth-term president, Walker-Myers—were incumbents dating back to Aldermania. Acharya could point to plenty of achievements: Elicker and the union-backed alders had passed the ordinance legalizing tenants' unions; they had steered pandemic-relief funds toward social services; they had pushed Yale to pay more in taxes. “I didn't realize how much the union was gonna feel like a political campaign,” Acharya told me. “It ;was; a political campaign.” ♦

;When Japanese audiences encountered Puccini's “Madama Butterfly”—a sumptuous Italianate treatment of a geisha's doomed love for an American naval officer—they found it implausible, insulting, and riotously funny. In 1925, two decades after the opera's première, the ;Japan Times; reported “screams of hearty laughter” as spectators took in the posturings of a touring foreign troupe. Puccini's habit of citing popular Japanese songs did not help matters. As Arthur Groos points out in “Madama Butterfly/Madamu Batafurai,” a new book about the opera's Japanese sources and reception, the composer ignored advice about how to use his material appropriately. When Suzuki, Butterfly's maid, prays at an alleged Buddhist shrine, she sings to the tune of “Takai Yama,” a song that extols cucumbers and eggplants. Furthermore, she garbles the names of Shinto gods, who don't belong in a Buddhist setting to begin with. It's similar, Groos writes, to “having a Catholic pray to Adam and Eve in front of a menorah.”

;

;Nevertheless, Japanese audiences and artists have continued to engage with “Butterfly,” not least because it has influenced Western perceptions of Japan for generations. In the fifties, the Fujiwara Opera, based in Tokyo, collaborated with New York City Opera on a bilingual production: Japanese singers took the Japanese roles, and white singers portrayed the callous Lieutenant Pinkerton and the more sympathetic consul Sharpless. The 1953 musical “Chōchō-san Sandaiki” (“Three-Generation Butterfly”) wove Puccini's characters and music into a tale of Japan under Allied occupation; the fact that the opera is set in Nagasaki added a shuddering layer of significance to that retelling. The scholar Mari Yoshihara, in a 2004 essay about the pioneering Japanese soprano Tamaki Miura, who won international fame as Butterfly, notes that the singer challenged restricted ideas of femininity at home.

;

;Today, as the American opera business grapples anew with the political baggage of its repertory, a fresh wave of “Butterfly” productions is arriving, with people of East Asian descent dominating the creative teams. Amon Miyamoto, Aria Umezawa, and Phil Chan have lately directed the work, at San Francisco Opera, New Orleans Opera, and Boston Lyric Opera, respectively. Earlier this month, at Detroit Opera, I saw a staging by Matthew Ozawa in which the story is framed as the increasingly disturbed fantasy of a modern American guy addicted to anime imagery and to VR technology.

;

;Some operagoers will inevitably protest that “Butterfly” should be left alone, as an innocent artifact of its time. Yet a work that delves into late-nineteenth-century sexual colonialism and makes ironic use of “The Star-Spangled Banner” cannot be stripped of its politics. As Groos and other scholars have noted, “Butterfly,” especially in its original version, has an anti-imperialist streak; Pinkerton, who goes through the motions of marrying Butterfly and then discards her, is a devastating caricature of cultural arrogance. After the opera's unsuccessful première, at La Scala, in 1904, Puccini softened the Pinkerton character, but there remains enough of the initial idea for directors to run with. Butterfly, for her part, may be hemmed in by Orientalist stereotypes, yet she draws power from the opulence of the music that Puccini wrote for her. Grotesque in some ways, greathearted in others, “Butterfly” is the kind of piece that not only invites but requires reflection on the part of performers and spectators alike.

;

;At the beginning of Ozawa's “Butterfly” in Detroit, we see a bored young man alone in his apartment, which is decorated with Japanese posters and tchotchkes. He gets a beer out of the fridge—Sapporo or Kirin, no doubt. You have the sense of an emotionally shut-down business bro who studied for a semester in Tokyo. He settles into a chair and picks up his VR gear, at which point his modern world dematerializes. Ceremonially clad characters step out of the fridge; imperial sets slide forward. When Pinkerton is not in a scene, the singer who plays him often hovers to the side, gesturing and twitching in an indolent trance.

;
;
;

;The framing is ingenious because it compensates for the opera's misbegotten notions of Japan. When Shinto names are mangled, or when Chinese folk songs come out of nowhere, we can blame the protagonist's muddled reverie. Even Puccini's most questionable choice in his revision of the score—giving Pinkerton an aria of bathetic remorse—can be justified as a spasm of performative self-pity on the part of the player's avatar. I remain convinced that the original “Butterfly,” in which the cowardly Pinkerton slinks away while “The Star-Spangled Banner” snarls dissonantly in his wake, is superior; New York City Opera's staging of it in 1993 transformed my perspective on the work. But I also recognize the practical need to give the lead tenor something a bit more gratifying to sing.

;

;Puccini, a sovereign artist terrified of commercial failure, tinkered with “Butterfly” for several years, steadily backtracking on his provocative initial conception. Ozawa drops some of the later changes, essentially adhering to a version that was presented in Brescia, several months after the première. The most crucial difference comes in the Act II aria “Che tua madre,” in which Butterfly, processing the news that Pinkerton has abandoned her, imagines her future and that of Dolore, her child. In the Brescia version, as in the original, she spins out a triumphant scenario in which Dolore is discovered by the Emperor and raised to a high station. Puccini later inserted a different, more lachrymose text, one that forecasts her suicide. The original Butterfly is a prouder, steelier character, a shade closer to the imperious Tosca.

;

;So she was in Detroit, in a formidable embodiment by Karah Son. Like many sopranos of East Asian background, Son has sung Butterfly over and over—in her case, more than three hundred times. She has not lapsed into routine. Her rendition of “Un bel dì” was a full-blown psychodrama, more a feverish hallucination of Pinkerton's return than a hopeful vision of it. Eric Taylor, as Pinkerton, brought to bear full-voiced lyric ardor while also communicating the character's rising unease over his entangled desires. Nmon Ford, as Sharpless, and Kristen Choi, as Suzuki, deftly navigated the show's imaginary landscape. Kensho Watanabe, in the pit, led a confidently paced, vibrantly colored performance.

;

;What I like most in this “Butterfly,” which has also played at Cincinnati Opera and will travel next to Utah Opera and Pittsburgh Opera, is its conjuring of stage pictures that are at once beautiful to look at and troubling to think about. Ozawa's collaborators—the design collective known as dots, the costume designer Maiko Matsushima, and the lighting designer Yuki Nakase Link—festoon the scene with glowing lanterns, cherry blossoms, and the like, but the images have a tacky, CGI-like glow. Sometimes figures freeze and lights flicker, signalling a breakdown in the smooth function of the fantasy. It wasn't clear to what extent the audience grasped the deconstructive agenda; I heard confused mutterings at intermission. The message of the closing tableau, though, should have been unmistakable. After Butterfly stabs herself, Pinkerton rushes onstage and clutches her, only to be left holding her bloody garment as she strides away. At the final, shocking triple-forte chord, she fixes the audience with an icy stare.

;

;There are days, many days, when I miss the old City Opera. It rejuvenated audience favorites, like “Butterfly,” which remained piles of bric-a-brac at the Met. It took chances on American singers instead of flying in jet-lagged European stars. And it featured new works that the bigger company discovered only decades later. The Met opened its current season with Jake Heggie's “Dead Man Walking”; City Opera presented the work in 2002, with the young Joyce DiDonato leading the cast. Coming in November is Anthony Davis's “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X,” which had its world première at City Opera in 1986. If the Met is looking for more inspiration in past City Opera seasons, it might consider Bernd Alois Zimmermann's “Die Soldaten” (1991), Erich Wolfgang Korngold's “Die Tote Stadt” (1975), and Alberto Ginastera's “Don Rodrigo” (1966). Or it could come up with new ideas.

;

;“X,” which Detroit Opera revived last year, is a major work whose impact has deepened with time. “Dead Man Walking,” based on Sister Helen Prejean's account of her friendship with a death-row inmate, made a feebler impression on its return to New York. It's an uncommonly popular piece, having been staged by more than seventy companies around the world. But the score is derivative and discursive, reacting to the story instead of driving it. At the Met, the opera felt like a movie of the week blown up to CinemaScope dimensions. Frantically loud orchestral playing, under the overeager baton of Yannick Nézet-Séguin, only amplified the music's limitations. DiDonato, again playing Sister Helen, and Ryan McKinny, as the inmate, were vocally secure and theatrically incisive; the production, by Ivo van Hove, undercut them with video trickery and a relentlessly chilly mise en scène. The execution scene had a clinical vividness, yet the barbaric politics of the death penalty remained an abstraction. Curiously, “Butterfly” in Detroit seemed more of the moment: it suggested how the virtual realm can infect and degrade the real one, turning us into prisoners of other people's fantasies. ♦
